sub_topic: Calculation of the number of electrons transferred in an electrochemical reaction
message_1:
What is the number of electrons transferred in the following electrochemical reaction:
2AgCl(s) + H2(g) → 2HCl(aq) + 2Ag(s) 

Hint: First, balance the oxidation and reduction half-reactions and then determine the number of electrons transferred in each half-reaction.
message_2:
First, we need to identify the oxidation and reduction half-reactions. In this case, Ag is being reduced (gaining electrons) and H is being oxidized (losing electrons).

Reduction half-reaction: AgCl(s) → Ag(s) + Cl^-(aq)
Oxidation half-reaction: H2(g) → 2H^+(aq) + 2e^-

Now, we need to balance the half-reactions. The reduction half-reaction is already balanced. For the oxidation half-reaction, we need to add 2Cl^-(aq) to the right side to balance the Cl atoms:

Oxidation half-reaction: H2(g) + 2Cl^-(aq) → 2H^+(aq) + 2e^- + 2Cl^-(aq)

Now, we can add the half-reactions together:

2AgCl(s) + H2(g) → 2Ag(s) + 2H^+(aq) + 2e^- + 2Cl^-(aq)

The number of electrons transferred in this reaction is 2.
